Description: Limestone statue of Ramses II, wearing nemes head-cloth and kneeling with an offering table, supported by a hes-vase, before; the hes-vase is inscribed with cartouches containing the names and titles of the king, his prenomen and nomen are also inscribed on the shoulders and the dorsal pillar of the figure; the lower section has been restored.
Curator's comments: Published: PM V: p. 97. HTBM Part 9: Plate VI. Kitchen, Ram. Insc. Vol 2, p. 550. Holzl, R, HAB: Agyptische Opfertafeln und Kultbecken, p. 201. Sourouzian, MDAIK 49 (1993), 250 n 47, pl. 49c.
Bibliographic references: James 1970 / Hieroglyphic texts from Egyptian stelae, etc., in the British Museum, Part 9. (Pl.6)
Shaw & Nicholson 1995 / British Museum Dictionary of Ancient Egypt (p209)
Exhibition history: Exhibited: 2001 26 Jun-23 Sep, Birmingham Gas Hall, Egypt Revealed 2008, 3 Mar-20 Jul, Cankarjev Dom, Slovenia, Pharaonic Renaissance. 2008, 4 Aug-9 Nov. Budapest, Museum of Fine Arts, Renaissance in Pharaonic Egypt. 2009 May-2024 Jan, Newcastle, Great North Museum, LT Loan Ancient Egypt British Museum Partnership Gallery
Associated names: Named in inscription & portrayed: Ramses II
